posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Will TVR really be back this year? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
Last year it was stated the production on the new TVR Griffith would start in early 2019. Now, they are saying it will be late 2019 for the 2020 model year - making the story start to sound eerily familiar to TVR fans. For those of you who aren't well versed with TVR as a brand, it was at one time TVR was the the third-largest specialized sports car manufacturer in the world. However, like a lot of great car companies, management messed it up. So, after a long wait and several ownership changes, TVR was "supposed" to be coming back in 2019 and we couldn't have been more excited by this announcement. Even if the odds of any Griffith making its way to us over here in America was pretty slim. This particular Paradise Purple Cerbera is a great example of why we love them. A lightweight car with an extremely powerful a 4.5 liter engine V8 that produced 420 bhp attached to a manual transmission. Living up to its namesake of the mythological beast who guarded the entrance Hades. Hopefully TVR will open up the gates to us and let this car pass through the river Atlantic and we can finally enjoy what so many of our European chasers have been for years 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1999 TVR Cerbera Speed Six Coupe
💯 53k miles
📰 @HistoricsAuctions
📸 @HistoricsAuctions
💵 Estimate: £15k - £19k
_______________________________________________

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Live on @pcarmarket: Does this car have you at yellow? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
The Porsche 964 3.6 Turbo is a car that's the stuff of dreams. And for most of us those dreams started right around the time Bad Boys was released. However, one thing we could never figure out is why someone as flashy as ‪Will Smith‬'s character would drive a black one. Wouldn't he want a Porsche like this example to match his unique personality and style? Only about 10% of these cars were made in a color other than Black, Red, White or Silver. So, it's pretty eye catching to see one like this cruising down the street. It also has a really neat history. The car was delivered new to a well-known race car driver at the Porsche factory in Stuttgart. He then shipped the car to back to Ohio and sold it two years later only to repurchase it from that owner in 2001. It was then kept in his private collection until 2012. What's even better is this car only has been driven 32K perfectly maintained miles. Meaning is that perfect combo of driver and collector car. It's currently being auctioned on @pcarmarket and the bids have been pretty steady which is not surprising. So, if you're interested we suggest placing a bid because we're not sure it will make it to their deal tank. Speaking of which, you should also prob check that out as there are some awesome cars in there for some good prices 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1994 Porsche 3.6 Turbo
💯 Speed yellow with sunroof delete
📰 @PCarMarket
📸 @PCarMarket
💵 Current bid: $210,000 (ends in 8 days)
_______________________________________________

Who had a Bigfoot Power Wheels? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
Unlike today, there wasn't a lot of choice when it came to which Power Wheels you wanted to park in your parents garage. You could have a blue Big Foot based on the Ford 250, a two seater Jeep Wrangler or pink Corvette. But, more important than choice was that once our parents were done putting it together (or in our case hiring the guy from the store to do it) we were going to get a taste of what it was like behind the wheel. For those of us who chose the Big Foot, it was an exhilarating experience to be at the helm of such a powerful machine. Well at least until the batteries ran out. Good news is we are all much older now and can park the real thing our driveways in the form of this 1978 Ford F250. While it's not the same color, it has a lot better aftermarket parts than a Transformers sticker. Things like a 6 inch lift kit, Holley 4-barrel carb and Magnaflow dual exhaust. So while we’re not yet sure of the estimate, it’s hard to put a price in reliving your childhood 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1978 Ford F-250 Pickup
💯 Frame off restoration finished in 2018
📰 @Mecum_Auctions Indy Sale
📸 @Mecum_Auctions
💵 Now accepting guesses in the comments

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Do you have a soft spot for Saabs? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
This is the first Saab we’ve ever posted on CCC and we don’t really think that’s fair. Saab has always had a small but memorable place in the car world as a quirky manufacturer that offered an alternative to what your neighbors had in their driveways. The Saab 900 was also a special car being one of the first mainstream turbocharged models ever produced (a legacy that’s only more pronounced today). It was safe, fun to drive and looked unlike anything else on the market. Given these cars were likely never deemed to be collectible and often went the distance with mileage, we think this is a pretty nice example having only traveled 61k miles. So do you share our sentiment on this car or is it just a Saab story? 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1979 Saab 900 Turbo 4-speed
💯 61k miles
📰 @BringaTrailer
📸 @InBound.Motorsports
💵 Current bid: $9,000 (3 days left)
_______________________________________________

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Which Cobra is King: 289 or 427? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
It might be everyone’s first impulse to go with the more powerful 427 Cobra but there’s more to the conversation that just raw HP and torque. Sure the 427 might win in a straight line but the 289 has been known to handle a lot better. Although the 427 is known to have a more comfortable ride. Then there’s the looks. To us, the 427s fenders are just too much. Particularly in the year where it’s a tad cartoonish. But then again, we own neither so we want to hear from you all. So to queue up the debate we’ve got prime examples of each. Up top, the only factory Stage III 289 Street Cobra ever built. Down below, an impressively original 427 with known ownership from new. So which will it be Chasers? 😎
_____________________________________________
🚙 1964 Shelby 289 Cobra Roadster
🚗 1966 Shelby 427 Cobra Roadster
💯 Best of the best cobras
📰 @Mecum_Auctions Indy Sale
📸 @Mecum_Auctions
💵 Guesses now accepted in the comments
_______________________________________________

Is this the ugliest Zagato car ever? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
Chances are - when you hear the name of the Italian coach builder, Zagato, cars like the Aston Martin DB4 and Vanquish Shooting Brake come to mind. However, back in the 90s, Zagato connected with 10 (let’s call them brave) Ferrari 348 owners to create the Zagato Elaborazione. Changes were purely cosmetic and for what we can only imagine was a hefty price tag, owners got their reimagined 348s with handmade aluminum panels, a custom interior (with 3 inch rear view screen), and a set of OZ racing wheels. We’ll leave it up to you what to make of this car but looking at these photos, we’re grateful no more than 10 were made 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1990 Ferrari 348 Zagato Elaborazione
💯 One of 10 produced
📰 @RMSothebys Villa Erba Sale

Do you love or hate the Series I? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
When Shelby announced he was making a new lightweight roadster and it would be the first one to actually bear his name, we were all pretty excited. Shelby was a legend and one of the most important car figures in our young lives after Enzo Ferrari. Then we all saw this and let's just say our excitement turned to disappointment. Even more so when we learned not only did it not have a Ford V8 but rather one from an Oldsmobile. To us, that was the super uncool car our grandparents drove and tried to pass down to us until we decided we'd rather walk instead of ever driving that car. Kidding aside the Aurora engine was a pretty solid choice since it was adapted from the ones being used in Indy cars at the time. This example is #130 of 249 produced and is all original down to the tires. Which makes sense considering it has only been driven 165 actual miles. So do you share our view or the Series I or are you a bit more optimistic? 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1999 Shelby Series 1
💯 165 original miles
📰 @Mecum_Auctions Indy Sale
📸 @Mecum_Auctions

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Restore or keep as is? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
This is one of our favorite questions to ask here at CCC and we only get to do it when cars like this come across our radar. You know the ones that have that perfect patina. Unfortunately, though it has had some body work done and a repaint. So, it's not entirely 100% original. That's why this question takes on even more relevance. But, the interior is all original and all of the numbers match the data card. Even cooler, the car only had one registered owner until 2018. Mechanically it's pretty sound too having just recently underwent a refresh. Meaning you can absolutely drive the car as is. So, with all that being said, what do you do? It's a tough choice especially since the value for freshly restored cars is climbing rapidly 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1962 Mercedes-Benz 190 SL
💯 77k miles shown
📰 @BringaTrailer via @DriverSource
📸 @iShootClassic
💵 Current bid: $50,000 (1 day left)

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Would you have paid $300k for this SL70 in 1998? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
It might be hard to believe looking at the prices of these cars today, but a R129 SL600 was only 5% cheaper than a Rolls Royce Silver Spirit when sold new. According to our research, that MSRP was about $125k. Add in the extra $50k or so to bump it up to a SL 70 and you’re looking at about $175k back then and nearly $300k in today’s dollars. With that level of sticker shock, we’re not surprised so few were ordered. On the other hand, that price got you access to a super car defying M120 V-12 pumping out 500 bhp in a sleeper package. So if we were partying like it’s 1999 and not 2019, would you have dropped $300k on this Merc? 😎
_____________________________________________
🚘 1998 Mercedes-Benz SL 70 AMG
💯 M120 V-12 pumping out 500bph
📰 @RMSothebys Essen Sale
📸 @TomWood_Photography
💵 Estimate: €125,000 - €175,000
_______________________________________________

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
This week we were saddened to learn the news that Samuel Tauster passed. A man who not only made a big contribution to the car world as one of the men behind the invention of the catalytic converter, but was also a special part of the CCC family. He was @JordanChasesClassics wife's grandfather. So today, as he climbs the stairway to heaven we only hope the car gods are there to meet him with his favorite car - the Mustang. And not just any Mustang, but a Boss 429 like this example. Since after all, the ultimate husband, father and grandfather deserves to spend eternity behind the wheel of the ultimate Stang. RIP Samuel. You will be missed 😎
_____________________________________________

💯 Ultimate Mustang for the ultimate grandpa

Is this SLK fooling anyone? #QOTD 🤷🏻‍♂️
.
.
.
We get why someone would want to make a car like this. Gullwings are just quite frankly out of the price range of most people. So, it’s a rather smart option if pulled off correctly. However, we’re not sure what to make of this one. It is a Mercedes at its core and not some hodgepodge of kit parts. And we do understand wanting stunning looks paired with modern driving dynamics, but it’s still really a 2000 SLK 320. Not exactly the racing DNA the original had. What’ the verdict Chasers? Does this fall in the camp of resto-stud or is it another big old resto-dud? 😎
_____________________________________________

💯 Guards Red over Cork interior
